sen.e: Yoshiisa OKU (1858-March 6 (or may have been 9th), 1933) was a gagakuka (musician of old Japanese court music) and composer in the Meiji, Taisho and Showa Periods.

sen.j: 1870年東上、宮内省雅楽局で雅楽を演奏し、また洋楽を教習した。
sen.e: He played gagaku (ancient Japanese court dance and music) in the Kunaisho Gagakukyoku (Music Department) of the Imperial Household Ministry in Tokyo in 1870, and toughed Western music.
sen.cmt: 「教習」は「知識・技術などを教えて修得させること」ですので、「教習した」はtaughtと訳したのですが、雅楽家が洋楽を教えるのは不自然な気がします。正しくは「修得」(learned）でしょうか。
sen.e: He went to the east capital, Tokyo and played gagaku (ancient Japanese court dance and music) in the Gagaku-kyoku (Music Department) of the Imperial Household Ministry in Tokyo in 1870, and taught Western music.

sen.j: 複数の『君が代』の中で、奥の『君が代』が祝日大祭日唱歌に選ばれた。
sen.e: Among several "Kimigayo" (Japan's national anthem), Oku's "Kimigayo" was selected as a song that celebrates Emperor's birthday.
